name: Hospital Incident Report - Ventilator Alarm Failure
description: Hospital incident report form documenting ventilator alarm failure in ICU. Structured form format with checkboxes and narrative sections.

raw_input.document_content:
MEMORIAL GENERAL HOSPITAL
PATIENT SAFETY INCIDENT REPORT

==============================================================================
REPORT INFORMATION
==============================================================================
Report Number: IR-2024-0892
Date of Incident: February 2, 2024
Time of Incident: 02:35 AM
Location: Medical ICU, Room 412
Reporting Staff: Jennifer Walsh, RN, BSN
Date Reported: February 2, 2024

==============================================================================
INCIDENT TYPE (Check all that apply)
==============================================================================
[ ] Medication Error
[ ] Fall
[X] Equipment/Device Malfunction
[ ] Procedure Complication
[ ] Security Issue
[ ] Other: _____________

==============================================================================
DEVICE INFORMATION (if applicable)
==============================================================================
Device Name: VitaBreath 7000 Ventilator
Manufacturer: RespiraTech Medical
Model Number: VB-7000
Serial Number: VB7K-2021-89234
Lot Number: VB-2021-L-0445
Purchase/Service Date: August 2021

==============================================================================
PATIENT INFORMATION
==============================================================================
MRN: 2847291 (Do not include in external reports)
Age: 67
Sex: M
Admission Diagnosis: Acute respiratory failure secondary to pneumonia
Current Status: Mechanically ventilated, sedated

==============================================================================
INCIDENT DESCRIPTION
==============================================================================
At approximately 02:35 AM, I was at the nurses' station when I noticed the patient's oxygen saturation dropping on the central monitoring system (from 96% to 88%). I went to the room and found the ventilator circuit disconnected at the Y-piece. The ventilator low pressure alarm had NOT activated, even though the disconnect had apparently been present for several minutes based on the trending data.

Upon inspection, the ventilator alarm system was set correctly (low pressure alarm at 5 cmH2O). The disconnect should have triggered an immediate alarm. Other nurses confirmed they had not heard any alarm.

I reconnected the circuit and the patient's saturation recovered to 95% within 2 minutes. Physician was notified.

==============================================================================
PATIENT OUTCOME
==============================================================================
[X] No apparent harm
[ ] Temporary harm requiring intervention
[ ] Permanent harm
[ ] Death
[ ] Unknown at time of report

Notes: Patient SpO2 dropped to 88% but recovered quickly after reconnection. No apparent lasting effects. Patient remains sedated and stable.

==============================================================================
IMMEDIATE ACTIONS TAKEN
==============================================================================
1. Reconnected ventilator circuit
2. Verified patient stabilization
3. Notified attending physician (Dr. Raymond Kim)
4. Tagged ventilator and removed from service
5. Replacement ventilator obtained from equipment pool
6. Biomedical engineering notified for device evaluation

==============================================================================
EQUIPMENT DISPOSITION
==============================================================================
[X] Removed from service
[X] Retained for evaluation
[ ] Returned to manufacturer
[ ] Discarded

Location of device: Biomedical Engineering, Tag #BME-2024-0156

==============================================================================
APPROVALS
==============================================================================
Reporting Nurse: Jennifer Walsh, RN_______ Date: 02/02/2024
Charge Nurse: Michael Torres, RN_________ Date: 02/02/2024
Risk Management: Sandra Chen_____________ Date: 02/03/2024

event_info.event_description: Ventilator low pressure alarm failed to activate when circuit disconnected at Y-piece. Patient's oxygen saturation dropped from 96% to 88% before nurse noticed on central monitor. Alarm settings were correct (5 cmH2O threshold). Disconnect present for several minutes without alarm.
event_info.patient_outcome: Temporary oxygen desaturation (88%), recovered after reconnection, no lasting harm
event_info.device_outcome: Removed from service, retained for biomedical engineering evaluation
event_info.location: Memorial General Hospital, Medical ICU Room 412

expected_complaint.narrative: Hospital incident report: VitaBreath 7000 ventilator (S/N VB7K-2021-89234) low pressure alarm failed to activate when circuit disconnected. Nurse noticed patient's SpO2 drop from 96% to 88% on central monitor, found circuit disconnected at Y-piece. Alarm settings verified as correct. Circuit reconnected, patient recovered. No lasting harm. Device removed from service for biomedical engineering evaluation.

ground_truth.coding_rationale: A0701 (Failure To Alarm) or A0702 (False Alarm/Failure to Alarm When Appropriate) for alarm not activating. MDR required because a ventilator alarm failure could lead to patient death if disconnect goes unnoticed longer.

extraction_challenges: Structured form format with checkboxes to interpret
Some fields may be partially filled
notes: Well-structured incident report with all required information clearly documented. Form format makes extraction straightforward despite formal structure.
